For c and d, I didn't do the same method as you but still came out with the same answer. For c, I used p=mv(50kg×10m/s=500kgm/s). Then I used P1-P0= 1000kgm/s(∆p). Then I made P1 the subject of the formula  Then for d, I used I=m*∆v(1000NS=50kg*(V1-V0) and I made V1 the subject of the formula

what if the velocity is unknown, how do i solve for it?

because he is using algebra to keep like terms on the same side of the equation.  1000N=50kg[Vf-10]  1000N/50=50kg[Vf-10]/50 (Divide both sides of the equation by 50)  20=[Vf-10] (After dividing both sides by 50, this is what we get. If you divide 1000 by 50 you get 20, and dividing the other side of the equation by 50 cancels the 50, leaving us with just [Vf-10])  20+10=[Vf-10]+10 (Now we add 10 to both sides. Just as dividing by 50 cancelled the 50 on the left side of the equation, adding 10 cancels 10 itself. This leaves us with [Vf])  30=[Vf] (By adding 10 to 20, we now get 30, meaning that Vf=30)   If this does not make sense please let me know,

I am sorry, but too many approximations. I stopped after the definition of momentum. Especially there is a confusion between the value of momentum (the norm of the vector) which is always positive and the projection of momentum on a given oriented axis, which can be positive or negative as any algebraic value depending on the chosen orientation of the axis (which is arbitrary). Every problem in physics starts with the specification of the referential and the coordinate system. One should clearly draw the axis with its associated unit vector. Then one should explicitly expand each vector in the chosen basis. This is essential to make it really comprehensible for the students. Best regards

A year late, but not necessarily. A resultant momentum is more like the sum of 2 vectors of momentum, whereas the final momentum would be the total momentum in the system. So while they could be equal, it depends on the definitions of your system that is being analyzed.
